intro: Galium aparine var. verum, commonly known as true cleavers, is a flowering plant in the Rubiaceae family. It is characterized by its prostrate growth habit and slender, hairy stems that cling to surfaces with small, hooked hairs. The plant produces small white or pale yellow flowers with five petals, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are opposite, simple, and oval-shaped with serrated edges. Galium aparine var. verum is often found in moist, disturbed soils along roadsides and in meadows.
